item.title: Discontinuities
item.description: Definition A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) is discontinuous at a point \(c \in \mathcal{D}\) if and only if \(f\) is not continuous at \(c\). That is, if the limit \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x)\) does not exist or is not equal to \(f(c)\). Types of discontinuities Let \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) be a function and \(c \in \mathcal{D}\). Then \(f\) has an infinite discontinuity at \(c\) if and only if \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) = \pm \infty\).

item.title: Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)
item.description: Theorem statement Let \(f: [a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) be continuous and let \(L \in \mathbb{R}\) be a number strictly between \(f(a)\) and \(f(b)\). Then there exists a \(c \in (a,b)\) such that \(f(c) = L\). Lemma Let \(a, L \in \mathbb{R}\) and let \(f\) be a function that is continuous at \(a\) with \(f(a) < L\) (\(f(a) > L\)). Then there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \(\vert x - a \vert < \delta\) implies that \(f(x) < L\) (\(f(x) > L\)).

item.title: Continuity
item.description: Continuous functions can be drawn without picking up your pencil. The \(\varepsilon\)-\(\delta\) definition, limit related definition A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) is continuous at a point \(c \in \mathcal{D}\) if and only if the limit of \(f\) at \(c\) exists and \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) = f(c)\). A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) is continuous if and only if it is continuous at the point \(c\) for all \(c \in \mathcal{D}\).

item.title: Functions
item.description: Definitions A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C}\) is a set of ordered pairs \((a,b)\) where \(a \in \mathcal{D}\) and \(b \in \mathcal{C}\) with the property that if \((a,b) \in f\) and \((a,c) \in f\), then \(b=c\). We call the set \(\mathcal{D}\) the domain of \(f\) and the set \(\mathcal{C}\) the codomain of \(f\). Notation If \((a,b) \in f\), we write \(f(a)=b\). Examples Polynomial functions are those of the form \[p(x) = \sum_{k=0}^n a_k x^k.

item.title: Infimum and supremum
item.description: Definitions Let \(A \subset \mathbb{R}\). We say \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) is an upper bound of \(A\) if and only if \(c \geq a\) for all \(a \in A\). We say \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) is a lower bound of \(A\) if and only if \(c \leq a\) for all \(a \in A\). We say \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) is the greatest/largest/maximum element of \(A\) if and only if \(c\) is an upper bound of \(A\) and \(c \in A\).

item.title: Sequences
item.description: An infinite list of things. Definitions For real numbers, a sequence is a function \(f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R}\), where the image of the number \(n\) under \(f\) is typically called \(a_n\). The sequence is written by listing its images: \(a_1, a_2, \dots\) or for short, \(\{a_n\}\). In a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), a sequence is a function \(f: \mathbb{N} \to X\), where the image of the number \(i\) under \(f\) is typically called \(x_i\).
